"I guess the magic section is in the underground." Baz said.

"Ooh, I feel so cold in here. It's like we're inside some kind of ice-monster's stomach..." Saz said, clinging closely to her brother.

The orb of eldrich light floating above them glowed brightly, but brought no warmth to their water-proof fur and skin. Baz hung an arm over his sister as he held her close.

"Don't worry, sis, just...Imagine that we're in a dungeon, searching for untold treasure! And best of all, it will contain books that can tell us where to find the Eye of Sarcous!" Baz said.

"Y-yeah, that's right...That's right! And no monster will stop the terrible twins!" Saz said, finally feeling relieved.

The two continued down their trek until the stairs ended, the floor leveling out. They continued to peer down the hall, unable to see anything beyond the engulfing darkness.

"I guess the only way is forward." Baz said.

And so the two walked on. After what felt like days to them (it was really just 15 minutes), the passage widened out, and the two continued walking on in the darkness.

"Baz...I'm getting...A bad feeling here." Saz said, clingy closely to her brother again.

"Uh...Don't worry, maybe this place is just the...Storage room?" Baz suggested.

Honestly, he was just as unsure as Saz was. Soon, the passage behind them disappeared as well, swallowed up by the darkness of the underground. The two stopped walking, looking back at where they came.

"Hey, where did the exit go?" Saz asked.

"U-uh...Don't worry, it's still there..." Baz said.

"But you won't make it there..." a voice said.

The darkness was suddenly expelled as the entire room became brightly lit as a sunny day. All around them, they saw various robed figures glaring at them. One of them moved to stand at the exit, blocking it. Baz and Saz stood back-to-back, sword raised and magic at the ready. There must've been about a dozen of them! Two dozen, even!

"What are intruders like you doing in the secret halls of the Sokrass Guild!?" one of the robed figures asked.

"W-we were looking for information about this rumor, about the Sarcous-something!" Baz said.

"Yeah! The bartender gave us a ring and told us to go to the library. We showed the ring, and the librarian guy let us come here." Saz said.

The robed figures looked back at each other, moaning things like "Argo again" or "Why does this keep happening!?" The figure who spoke to them approached the two, removing the hood to reveal a male red panda anthro, looking to be about his mid-40s. He had a somewhat rough-looking face, but was still good-looking. "Sorry about that. Argo, the bartender who led you here, is a member of ours. The problem with him is that he keeps allowing complete strangers here, just because they happen to be spirited adventurers. Honestly, half of our members joined us only because they were led here, just like you two." he explained.

Baz and Saz lowered their armaments as they calmed down. "Oh. So, does this mean that we're going to have to join too?" Baz asked.

"Well, you two came here to learn about something related to magic and wizardry. The only way you will be allowed to search through our archives is if you are members." the red panda explained.

"Oh. So, I guess that means we'll be joining anyway, then." Saz concluded.

"Well, you two seem to be rather calm. Very well. To join, you must make a vow to never reveal these secrets to anyone outside of the Sokrass Guild. First, your names."

"Right. My name is Baz, and this here is my twin sister Saz." Baz said, holding Saz's hand.

"Good." The guild members then converged on the two, forming a circle around them. The red panda then held out a hand to the two, speaking in a tone similar to when the twins first arrived. "Otter Baz, and otter Saz. Do you swear to uphold our laws, never to breath a word of our knowledge to those of outside the Guild? To share your knowledge with us, your brothers and sisters? And lastly, to accept any punishment should you ever betray us?" the red panda said.

"Yes, we vow to uphold your laws." Baz said confidently. "Me too!" Saz said.

"Very well. You two are now official members of the Sokrass Guild. Remember this day, and never tell of our secrets to outsiders." the red panda said.

One of the members left the room, passing through one of the walls. Baz was amazed to see it, until Saz told him that it must've been an illusionary spell, making a wall appear there, when there was no wall at all. The member came back, carrying a pillow with two rings that look exactly the same as the one Argo the bartender gave them. Baz and Saz took one each, wearing it on their ring fingers. However, they were a little loose. With this little ceremony over, the other members took off their hoods, revealing their own faces to the two. There were quite a number of anthros there, including a blue-scaled dragon, a raven, and one that looked like a white shark. The red panda mumbled something as the walls all shimmered and melted away, revealing a large library that looked as big as the one on the surface. the various members began going about in their own business, either chatting with each other or reading a book. The red panda was the only one who remained with Baz and Saz.

"Wait, we don't get fancy robes?" Saz said, mindlessly pulling at her own green robes. Her robes looked old and worn out compared to the members' robes.

"Those are home-made. Now, allow me to introduce myself. My name is Rasputin, although everyone here calls me Raz. I am the guild master, which basically makes me the leader. Now that you two are members, you are welcome to peruse through our books and scrolls." Raz said.

"Oh, well thank you very much Raz, sir! But, we only came here to learn more about this Sarcous' Eye thing." Baz said. "Yeah! We thought that this would be the perfect journey! So we decided that finding this Sarcous thingy will mark our first step as adventurers!" Saz said eagerly.

"So, you mean to say that you two are still novices?" Raz asked, slightly dumbfounded.

"Well, technically, yes..." Baz admitted.

"Then, I suggest that, for the sake of your lives, you search elsewhere for your first adventure. The Eye of Sarcous is too dangerous for novice adventurers such as yourselves." Raz said, turning away.

"No! We agreed to set out for this, and we're going to stick to it!" Baz said, getting worked up. "We didn't leave our hometown just to turn our tails and run like cowards! We're gonna stick to this journey, and we'll stick to it until it's finished!" Saz said.

"Hmm...Perhaps, Argo may have seen something in you two after all...Very well. Roger!"

The raven anthro looked up from his scroll before walking up to them. "Yes Raz? You need me for something?" he asked. "Roger, fill these two in on what we know of the Eye of Sarcous. I will...Fetch something from the vault."

With that, Raz left them. Roger looked at the two newest members, who just smiled and waved at him. Roger rolled his eyes and told them to follow him. They went to a nearby table and told them to sit and wait, which the twins did. Roger began going through several books in one of the shelves, finally pulling out the one he wanted and set it in front of the two. It was thick, or should've been. The cover was meant for thicker tomes, but the book itself only had several pages in it, and most were really old and worn-out.

"It took the guild quite a few years of searching to find this, and find this we did. This is a journal kept by one of the mage companions of Sarcous himself." Roger said excitedly.

"So, this is from one of this Sarcous guy's friends? Then they must know about the guy himself!" Baz said.

"Yes, but sadly, it was badly damaged when the mage disappeared. It contains a few things about what Sarcous researched. Here..." Roger opened the book, showing a page that showed a very unrecognizable creature. It was humanoid in shape, and had something that looked like clothing. "This is a picture of Sarcous himself. The only picture, in the entire world. And here..." Roger flipped the book to a page with a picture of a pendant. It had some kind of eye on it. "This is the Eye of Sarcous, what you two are looking for. You see, it's believed that Sarcous found magic meant only for gods and immortals. When he disappeared, this pendant and a message were the only things left behind. 'The eye will lead you to the orb' it said. So now, we search for this Orb of Sarcous, and use its power to better this world. That is the purpose of the Sokrass guild."

Roger closed the book, leaving the twins in awe. Raz soon returned, wearing something over his robe. The twins looked at it, and it looked like the pendant in the book!

"Is that..." Baz said. "The Eye thingy?" Saz asked. Raz nodded his head. "Yes, that is correct. We have indeed found the actual pendant. However, no matter how hard we tried to keep it a secret, there is just no stopping the rumors from spreading. But when we obtain the Orb of Sarcous, then we can use its power to heal this world from its suffering." Raz said.

"Cool...So, where is the Orb?" Baz asked.

"Ah, allow me to explain..." Raz began. "We found out that, in a place where there is a high concentration of magic, we can use the pendant to take us to where the orb hides."
1432.title: Getting "Recruited"

choices: They found themselves in some kind of village...But something's off...
They found themselves elsewhere?
14321.content:
Baz and Saz just looked at each other, delight and excitement etched all over their faces. They were almost squealing at each other, unable to wait for the time to come. Raz and Roger just looked at the two, unsure if they were mentally ill or not. They were about to ask when they suddenly looked up to Raz and exploded with a series of questions about what will happen. Raz managed to calm them down long enough to tell them that he has no idea what will happen once they use the pendant. Even so, Baz and Saz began imagining what will happen when the time comes.

"Maybe a huge door will open up!" "Yeah, and it'll take us to a room filled with all kinds of cool things! Like a bunch of spell books!" "Or a dozen swords made of solid gold!" "Or a pile of scrolls big enough to fill up the guild!" "Or even a mountain of treasure! We'd all be rich!" "Yeah! And maybe, everyone in the village will see how right we are."

Baz and Saz gave a content sigh as they began remembering their village. Everyone tried to talk them out of the adventuring business, but they were too dead-set on it. They finally relented and allowed them to go off on their own. They even saw them off as they left the village.

"What was that last part about your village?" Roger asked.

"Oh...Well, everyone back in the village said that we're getting too full of ourselves, wanting to go on a grand adventure." Baz said.

"But once we complete this adventure, we'll show them that we have what it takes! We aren't just a couple of kids way over our heads!" Saz said.

"Besides, we're 18..."

Raz just smiled and reminded them that their first adventure won't start until tomorrow. He then led the two through the library, reaching a door. There, he opened it and revealed a large room full of beds. This must be where the guild members sleep in. Raz told them that they can take the two beds by the window. Baz and Saz then walked up to the two beds, setting their stuff down on it. Raz told them that they're free to do as they please until then, leaving the two by themselves. Baz and Saz looked out the window, seeing the sun still high up in the sky. With that, they decided to spend the time getting to know the other members of the guild. They started out with Roger.

"Hey Roger. We were wondering...Have you always been a member of this guild?" Baz asked.

"As a matter of fact, yes. I joined the guild when I was studying Sarcous and I first found the old journal I showed you earlier. I guess you may consider me as the co-founder, alongside Raz."

"Oh, cool! Well, alright. See you later!" Saz said.

The two moved on to getting to know the other members. They talked with the blue dragon, who was named Dorcas.

"So, were you always a member of the guild?" Saz asked.

"No, not really. I'm an adventurer, like you two. I've been traveling for at least a year by now, and I wound up here thanks to the rumor, and that bartender Argo."

"What was adventuring like, then?" Baz asked.

"Oh, it was fun! I got to fight bandits, explore dungeons, solve traps and riddles, it was the life! Though a lot of times, I do miss the town I left behind. I don't regret it, really. I'm sure they miss me too."

Baz and Saz nodded to each other as they moved on. They began talking to the white shark. His name was Marcus.

"So Marcus...Were you an adventurer like us?" Baz asked.

"Yup! Except I've only been adventuring for about a few months. I've explored a dungeon or two, but that's about it. Wound up here thanks to a 'fateful' visit at the tavern."

"So, you're still pretty new to adventuring then?" Saz said.

"Yeah. Not as green-horned as you two, of course, but I still don't know that much. Anyway, shouldn't you two be reading a book or something? You'll wanna know what we're facing when tomorrow comes."

Baz and Saz looked at each other before bidding Marcus goodbye. They talked about Marcus having a point, so they looked at the vast collection of books in the library. They both took a book to read, flipping through the pages. Baz was reading some mage's study of Sarcous, and why his research is actually fake, or something. Saz managed to pick out a spell book, and was now looking through the vast number or spells she could learn to use. The two spent hours reading through their books, not noticing the time they've spent.

"Alright you two, I think it's time to rest." Raz said, walking up to them.

"H-huh? How long have we been reading?" Baz asked, rubbing his tired eyes.

"Oh, several hours. It's already sunset, and we all have to get up early tomorrow. We wouldn't want you two to sleep through it, now would we?"

"Y-you're right! Saz, come on! We need to get some rest."

"J-just a minute! I need to know how to speak the incantation for this flame-pillar spell." Saz said, still reading.

"Ah, you've taken quite a liking to our spell books, young mage? You can bring that to bed, if you wish. Just remember not to overdo it."

"Oh, thanks Raz!" Saz said, smiling.

The two headed to the sleeping area, seeing some of the members already on their beds.

"Some members want to stay in the guild. Others prefer sleeping in the town's inn. With over a dozen members, it's understandable some of them want privacy." Roger said, looking up from his bed.

Baz and Saz slipped into their beds. Baz looked out the window, seeing the last traces of sunset before night fully sets in. Saz was still reading through the spell book, muttering some incantations under her breath.

"Hey Baz, check this out!"

Saz extended her arm out before muttering something. Baz looked on expectantly as her hand glew red. Suddenly, a pillar of fire shot out, scorching the ceiling. Roger, along with every other member present, looked at her. Saz coughed a bit as she apologized before closing the spell book.

"Alright Saz, bedtime." Baz said.

-----

"Wake up you two!"

The two otters were shook awake as Roger stood before them. They rubbed the sleep out of their eyes as they looked at him.

"What's going on? I want five more minutes..." Baz said.

"The ceremony's about to start! Raz will use the Eye of Sarcous to open the gateway! Right now!"

That shook them fully awake. They scrambled to tget their stuff ready as they followed Roger to the center of the guild. There, everyone was standing behind Raz as he held his arms out to his sides. He looked back to see the last three arrive.

"Ah, good of you to arrive. I told you two to go to sleep early." he said.

"S-sorry. We were so excited, we couldn't get much sleep." Saz said.

"That's alright. Now, we will begin."

Raz began muttering a long string of arcane words, the kind that only mages like Saz could understand. The pendant around his neck began to glow as an orb of light appeared in front of everyone. The orb grew larger and larger, pulling itself wider until a glowing, swirling portal appeared in front of everyone.

"Is everyone prepared?" Raz asked.

There were murmurs of approval as they stared into the portal.

"Very well. Let us go retrieve the orb!"

And with that, everyone stepped through...
14321.title: Start Of The Journey

choices: Deliver the Letter
Prefer the Hex
Create Another Party
15.content:
Two figures, adorned in simple leather armour, weapons at the ready, stood back to back in a warzone. Not your traditional setting for such fanfare mind you, at a humble townsquare.

The township of Katora was under attack! It had been for several days now. How quickly it had turned from a quaint and picturesque home for the moderately rich and educated into a twisting pile of fire and rubble would astound the most hardened warrior. The place was anarchy! All the civilians that could flee had done so, brutish thugs pillaged houses and clashed on the street constantly, enterprising bandits were smuggling weapons and claiming territory, while thieves treated the place like a playground. Any poor guard still standing were running around like headless chickens just trying to keep themselves alive, waiting for the cavalry from the capital to arrive.

The two figures in the townsquare were none of those things. Rubin and Crom, travelling hunters, red kangaroo and white rabbit, they were in the wrong place at the wrong time.
Friends since childhood, they enjoyed a simple life of fishing and sometimes slaying minor wild monsters, living for months in the seclusion of nature, though nothing made them more cheerful than returning to their home village to see friends and family, and to get drunk.

Their drunken antics were the cause of why these two had not made a hasty leave as soon as the conflict started, like so many others. Locked up for disturbing the peace and brawling (each other), they were unlucky enough to be put behind bars just before all the pandemonium started, and woke up to find a grisly scene had become of their warden, who had the key.

They spent two days behind bars, and soon feared they might perspire of thirst if not for some stupid bandit who entered the jail to loot it, and was tricked into opening the cell door by their combined jeers and taunts about his portly visage. Even in their weakened state and without weapons they adeptly took out the fat thug. Crom, the more serious and thoughtful type, thought it might be best to off him, but Rubin, the more cocky and relaxed one, felt it was morally wrong to do in a collapsed enemy, even if he did just try to kill them. So they looted his swords, left him in the cell, locked it, and threw the key through the bars into the waste bucket.

Then they kept low, broke into a nearby pie shop that seemed mostly untouched by the madness, and managed to find some supplies in there and recovered for a few hours. After having starved for days both hunters abandoned sensible restraint and ate stale abandoned food until they were both sickly bloated. But it was better than being hungry they agreed.

Then they heard a noise, and quickly figured out their hidout was not actually abandoned.

They readied their weapons, though anxious, neither feeling ready to battle so soon after their gorging.

A smug feminine laugh was heard, but its origins not seen, “Lay down your dinky weapons silly boys, if I wanted to smite you I’d have killed you each before I’d come inside.” A black arrow shot from the darkness of an upstairs loft, it hit the wooden floor by Rubin’s feet and he let out an embarrassing yelp as he hopped away. “I- uh, state your business then! Or let us leave!… please?” Crom spoke, trying to not let intimidation creep into his words, but knowing he was at this shadow girl’s mercy.

“I choose neither” she flatly refused, “I don’t dignify petty thieves like you with my mission.” She shot another arrow, it flew in-between Crom’s long ears, intentionally missing, and it was Crom’s turn to foolishly duck and cower while whimpering.

“Heh… but I don’t intend to kill you… not directly anyway…” the figure spoke again, deliberately pacing her words in a slow and chilling manner, “do you simpletons even know why there is such calamity that has befallen Katora?... No of course you wouldn’t… an artefact… of great value… was recently discovered here… the fools… put it on display… heh heh heh…”
“Oh get on with it!!” Rubin finally yelled out, his fear being replaced by impatience.
“Quiet Rabbit”
“I-I’m not a bloody rabbit! HE’s a rabbit lady, I’m a proper kanga-“
“Quiet!” An arrow shot out dangerously close to Rubin’s neck, and Rubin shut up.
“Anyway simpletons, I will let you live, but you must deliver an item for me- and don’t get any ideas of stealing it or running off because it’s hexed!
Take this letter to the grand library, heh, the place were the pendant was stored, it is where a great bandit leader is. The letter is for him. He’s… a wild one… heh… I’m pretty sure he’ll let you live if he receives it quickly and in one piece… if anyone stops you say you’re a messenger from Perralace, that may save you…” for a brief moment the woman leaned out of the shadows and their hunters saw a beautiful jaguar woman before she concealed her face with a purple scarf and turned to leave out the loft window into the night, “now go thieves”.

So, as was established at the start, at the town square, under the threat of hex, Rubin and Crom have a package to deliver before they can get out of this crazy town. The town square stands opposite the great Katora Library, now half smouldering ruins, half bandit encampment. The grim threat of walking into that den seems almost as bad as any hex, even making the hunters pause to consider.
15.title: Rubin and Crom

choices: Talk to Crusher
Try to escape!
151.content:
Keeping an eye out for rooftop archers or other threats, running between ornamental trees, toppled statues and garden tables for cover, the pair of hunters slowly made their way towards the library. They were lucky to have attracted minimal attention on their way here, only a few times having to defend against wayward attackers and once escaping a gang of nasty warriors down some side streets.

The question now was how would they get inside? The place was heavily guarded by devious looking rouges, all camped outside the perimeter, “guarded” being a term used very loosely. They were drinking, fighting and singing old pub songs like they were having a wild party, neither Crom nor Rubin wanted to approach, but at least these guys seemed less bloodthirsty than the average cutthroat they’d see so far.

Crom tucked his sword into his belt and held his arms up, palms open to show he was no thread as he hailed them. “Hey! Hallo! I need too, ehn… I need to speak to whoever is in charge here!” he yelled, grabbing everyone’s attention. The festive attitude instantly dissipated as angry bandits glared at the intruders with hate and weariness. Rubin counted at least three crossbows pointed at him, he could feel a nervous sweat on his brow.

A monolithic tiger man stood up, arm clutching a spiked club and heavy shield, wearing nothing but battlescars over his muscular chest, “What inspires two runts like you to approach the fearsome Basalt Brigand Gang, do you have a death wish?” He finished with a menacing growl that sent shivers up Crom’s spine, “I-I… have a delivery! Oh I was sent by Porice... Pearlice?… Perralace!”

As soon as Crom spit out her name the great tiger man’s expression softened, then he burst out with raucous laughter! “HAHAHA-Hahaha, surely another soppy love letter for Herc no doubt, well let me see it and you may come in brothers, and stop shaking in your boots you’re in good company here.”

Crom fumbled for the letter and presented it to the grinning tiger; he inspected a sign on it and waved to his men to open the large oak library doors. Rubin let out an audible sigh of relief, now they just had to give this “Herc” guy his letter, thank him for not cutting them up, and say goodbye before they could get far away from here and end this story. Should be easy enough he thought!

The large tiger escorted them through the total mess that was once a library, a large bonfire of books burned in the main hall, lighting everything with a sinister glow. As they climbed a passage of ruined stairs to a special tower room Rubin tried to strike up some conversation, “Soo eh, the lady who sent up, who mistook us for thieves –“
“mistook?” the Tiger interrupted, “looks like thieves to me”
“I…? Well sorry we aren’t, we’re actually fine upstanding citizens man, great hunters and traders”
“Perra doesn’t bother normal citizens, mate.”
“Yes well she did”
“Are those your swords? They don’t look like your size”
“Uhh, well no but-“
“Knew it”
“Hey that no fair, we-“
“Save it rabbit, we’re almost there”
“I’m not a stinkin rabbit! See this great tail, its full blown kanga- oof!” Crom punched Rubin for being an idiot and insulting his kind.
“Hahaha” the tiger spoke, “you guys are alright, my names Bart, friends call me Crusher, you can call me Bart.”
Rubin and Crom exchanged a sly glance. They were heading down a long hallway now; they had to be heading to the very back of the library. “Soo Bart...” Crom spoke, “why are you here? I mean, why does it seem like every criminal and mercenary in the country has descended on this place, the lady who sent us here seemed to know”
“And you don’t?” Bart spoke with surprise, “The darn Eye of Sarcous is here, you damn fool, its worth a kings fortune to the right people, stupid magic folk who think a spell is better than a weapon you can hold…”
“And this would cause everyone to descend at once on this town?” Crom inquired in disbelief, trying to divert the fact he was totally ignorant of what an “Aii of Sacouus” as Bart pronounced it actually was.
“Argh, there be darker forces at play here, we came cause we were commissioned... I’ll not say by who, but Herc suspects most of the other big factions were payed off too. Long standing rival feuds boiled over and suddenly a simple raid escalates into all out war! And then the opportunists like you two joined the fray.
It’s a damn disgrace, we lost a lot of good men last night in an attack *sniff*” Suddenly sounding sentimental.
“Well if you have the uh.. I of Sadus… why don’t you just leave?”
“What? And lead everyone back to our base to ruin? We wouldn’t even make it back alive, fucking Cobalt Gang... And besides the boss says we still have stuff to do here.”

“And why is it, dear Crusher, that you are telling these strange strangers our plans?” A cool but authoritative voice spoke out. They had arrived to finally see Herc, the bandit leader.

Herc was a white wolf, with piercing amber eyes, lounging lazily on a plush leather armchair with his large metal tipped boots resting on some expensive looking desk. Dressed loosely like a bandit, but wearing lots of gold and jewels, incredibly gaudy. The most prominent gold piece he wore was a large and highly decorative pendant.

“Uhh, sorry boss, I didn’t tell them anything important sir, honest! They have a message from Perralace!”
“What? Give it to me, now!” Herc sat up intently and held out his hand demanding. Crom quickly handed the letter over, “Well uh, you got what you wanted so I guess we’ll be going now? Nice to see you, bye-bye” he grabbed Rubin by the arm and tried to walk out but Bart stood in the doorway and wouldn’t let him pass. Crom’s ears drooped as his spirits lower; of course it wouldn’t be that easy.

As Herc finished reading the letter, a sly grin slowly grew over his face (and a slight blush, there must have been something dirty written in that letter…), “Keh heh heh heh, she found it! She found the door! Crusher, tell our men to pack up, we’re heading out” Bart nodded intently and ran off.

“Hmm, as for you two, you know too much…” Herc lifted a frighteningly large cutlass up from under the table with on arm, the two hunter’s hearts skipped a beat, and both were seconds away from pulling out their own comparatively crappy swords, though they were clearly outmatched.
“You’ve got two options, I kill you, or… you work for me!” He declared and plunged the cutlass into the desk. Rubin and Crom shot each other a surprised and confused glance.
“You’re lucky, if I wasn’t currently so low on men the choice would be clearly to kill you, but dire circumstance dictate otherwise.
I just need you for this one job, then I’ll let you go, heh, I’ll even give you a great reward if you don’t fuck up.
But if you even think of betraying me I’ll make sure you’ll WISH you picked death right hear and now!”

The hunters were speechless, after a moment of processing what was asked of them Crom nodded furiously, then nudged Rubin to start nodding too.

“Good, take these and get out of my sight” he threw them each a token from his pocket, it bore the gangs insignia, a sign of membership, “talk to Crusher for orders, maybe he’ll even have some spare weapons to replace your sorry excuse for butterknives.”

Crom and Rubin left Herc with a heavy feeling of dread hanging over them; they were in way over their heads.
151.title: Bandit Life

choices: a dimly lit cavern like room
a open field, lush with strange plants
1511.content:
As the hunters returned to the main hall they saw a much different sight than the partying going on earlier, the bonfire was extinguished and everyone was frantically loading chests or equipping for travel. Herc had a large party of bandits working for him, even if he said he was understaffed, back at the door was Crusher.

Making sure to loudly brandish their new membership tokens all the way, Rubin and Crom walked over to him and explained what they had been told.

Bart was happy to exchange their improvised weapons with a fine sword and shield for Rubin and a spear for Crom, made from the groups own blacksmith, a buff golden brown scaled dragon nicknamed FireHammer.

They quickly met quite a few other members of the group too, including an older alchemist bear called Loagi, two jokester assassin cats called Jin and Jang, a lusty fox mage named Bruce, a wise Druid zebra named Alec, a young archer pandagirl name Liz and a meanspirited sharkmorph named Rex. But there were many others.

They helped move boxes and load wagons until Herc himself descended down the stairs into the main room; he walked with a stride like he was king of the world. “Right men, I trust we’re ready to move out, we’re not going far, to the cemetery ahoy!”

***

The Bandit group made their way through the streets swiftly, as quick as they could.
Crusher was keeping his eyes firmly on Rubin and Crom to make sure they didn’t try anything funny in the transit.
“So –huff- why are we going to a grave yard again? –huff-” inquired Rubin to the watchful tiger as they jogged.
“-huff- Not that it concerns you –huff- but Perra has found an opening to –huff- Sarcous’ tomb! –huff-”
“What?” inquired Crom, “here in Katora? But... that zebra fellow who explained all this Eye of Sarcous nonsense to me, said he disappeared thousands of years before Katora even existed, hell, he said he disappeared, not died, why would he even have a tomb??”
“No stupid,” Bart replied, Crom glowered, he hated being called dumb, “It’s not Sarcous’ own tomb –huff-, it’s called that because it’s to tomb of anyone who enters it. –huff-”
“I see, but that doesn’t explain why it’s in Katora”
“It’s not in Katora, ugh, difficult to explain –huff-… it’s in another realm, pocket world created by Sarcous, we’re heading to a portal –huff- to take us there”
“Okay why is there a portal to a magical realm in Katora and nobody ever heard of it?”
“Argh, we’re summoning the portal there, -huff- it’s the only place in this stupid town that has the right summoning conditions –huff- you ask way too many questions long ears…”

Though overwhelming force the bandit group dispatched any who dared get in their way on their march to the graveyard, but the group as a whole was nervous, they had been lucky to not run into any other large gang or ambush.
They were sure they were being watch though, after all they had the prize most of the warmongers in the town were after.

The graveyard was a hilly place, unkempt, gothic, largely untouched by the strife engulfing the town. On the tallest hill was a church, and the jaguar woman, Perralace, stood outside of it waving a lantern.

When the bandit group reached her the first thing Herc did was embrace her for a passionate kiss.

But there was a few other figures standing alongside her, a princely looking coyote, flanked by guards and a few robed members who appeared to be wizards.
Herc’s oddly respectful demeanour towards the coyote told Crom that he was the group’s mysterious commissioner Bart had mentioned earlier. He looked like the typical spoiled brat evil heir to a vast fortune, if he could, Crom would be slaying this guy on the spot for the damage he’s caused, sadly circumstance did not permit.

Then everyone went right to business like true professionals. Orders for several skulls to be collect, a bucket of water, flowers and other such things to be scavenged for the summoning. Alec, Bruce, Loagi and a few others were setting up the spell, drawing markings around the church door, sometime squabbling between each other about if a symbol was right or wrong.

All in all it took less than an hour; a sliver of sunlight was rising on the horizon, signalling morning had come.

Everyone gathered around to watch the wizards recite an ancient incantation. The doors before them, started to transform, from a plain old dirty wood door, it turned deep red and intricate carvings of fruit and vines appeared, it even actually grew in size a little, fracturing the surrounding wall. In the center a lock appeared, in the shape of an eye. When the process was done it positively glowed.

After everyone was done being amazed by old magic Herc stepped forward, he was clutching the pendant around his neck in both hands. Crom noticed it also had the image of an eye on it. “The eye will lead you too the orb, the eye will lead you too the orb” the wizards chanted. Then the rabbit realized the pendant so many people were after was infact a key!

Herc pushed the pendant into the pupil of the lock’s eye, there was a loud bang and suddenly the double doors opened, slowly at first, creaking awfully. When it had fully opened it presented not the inside of the church, but a swirling red wall of light, smoke billowed out and covered the floor.

“Hurry everyone inside” Perralace spoke, ushering the crowd with her hands, “remember! This door will only be open for one full day; if it shuts while we’re still inside then we’ll be stuck. We can’t bring the pendant inside, and we can’t rely on it being reopened any time soon if it closes.”

“W-what?” Rubin muttered to Crom, “they didn’t mention this before! I don’t want to be trapped in some dank tomb forever, I’m too young and handsome to be a mummy!”
“Shh Rubin, we’ll make sure we get out of here alive, I know we can, we’ll just look out for each other.”

Not that they had a choice, the pair of hunters walked to the door like everybody else, finally when they stepped inside they saw…
1511.title: Meet the crew and travel

choices: they reached a bridge
they heard footsteps behind them, their waring rivals had followed inside
15112.content:
It was a strange sight to behold; they stepped inwards and entered outwards, into a huge open world distinctly foreign to their own. A pink sky canvassed the landscape, a forest of blue and purple plants encircled their clearing. Some strategically placed rocks with strange patterns carved into them dotted the ground.

Once the last of them were inside Crom stood on one of those rocks to command his troops. Relaying various orders but Rubin and Crom weren’t really listening, they were too busy taking in the sights.

“Whoa, Crom, this place is amazing.”
“I know, how could that Sarcous guy make all this…” suddenly a pair of black paws landed on both of their shoulders, startling each of them. “With that ultimate magic he encountered boys; even with just a little bit he created all this place!” it was Loagi the alchemist, “but be wary, it’s not called Sarcous’ Tomb for nothing. So few have entered and ever returned, none with the fabled orb of power. Their historical accounts of this place are sketchy at best, describing it as corrupt and perverse, nothing to be trusted, so young ones like you best be careful, eheheheh”.

“and you two best stop slacking and help carry some supplies, rabbits!” Bart yelled at them, Rubin scowled.

The group then proceeded to follow a path out of the clearing; apparently it was the right way because the magic folk could read the special stones scattering the path. It was pretty exhausting work, ontop of everything else the hunters had dealt with that day already.

It was when they were trudging by a long canopy of oddly coloured fruit that the first incident that marked the strangeness of this place presented itself.

Up ahead of Rubin and Crom there was suddenly a commotion, Jin, the jokester cat assassin, was being wacked over the head by a pissed off Alec with his druid staff, “Ow! Hey, ow stop!”
“You fool, why did you consume the fruit, you could have been killed!”
“Ow! Jang dared me! Ow! And I’m not dead, or I might be if you don’t stop hitting me with that damn stick!”
“Well how do you feel?” Liz asked with concern. “Rrrgh, besides some bumps on my head now… I… I actually feel kind of great!” Jin said, “Wow, but… I do feel different, everything feels… lighter?”
“You feel lightheaded! That’s not good” Liz replied. “No, no. I mean everything feels lighter!” he suddenly grabbed the kind of chubby panda girl and lifted her over his head with ease. “Waaa, put me down!”

After some brief testing, it was confirmed that somehow the fruit had made the lithe cat boy somehow as strong as the giant tiger Bart! The group mage performed a simple detect sickness spell on the assassin, and determined that he was in perfect health.
There was one odd drawback however, whereas before Jin had been skin and bones, there was now a small dome of chub centred on his belly. He was very displeased he now had a small potbelly, and his brother Jang teased him mercilessly about it.

Now a difficult question was posed to the group of bandits, should they partake of the strange fruit and make their journey easier, or stay weary (and totally skinny)? They had to decide soon though; they had waisted enough time on this distraction already.

“Rubin,” Crom spoke to his friend, “I know what you’re thinking, it’d be great to be super strong, but I really don’t think we should eat these things, you heard what the alchemist bear said earlier, this place can be really dangerous…”
“Buddy come on! Super strength! And guess what? That odd bear guy is eating one of them fruits as we speak.”
Crom turned around to see it was true, the black bear was greedily chowing down. “Ugh, that’s not the point, I get a… a bad feeling about them. Plus they’ll make you fat”
“Heh, firstly Crom, scientific magic has assured us they are perfectly safe, and secondly it’s only a little bit of pudge, I could work it off in a week if I tried! Well, I’m going to try it, with out without you…”
“Certainly without, I just hope your right about this…”
Rubin plucked one of the pear-like fruits off of an overhanging branch, there were hundreds of them, all icy blue.

With a little hesitation Rubin opened his maw and took a big bite out of it. It tasted very sweet, like custard.

The pair waited a few seconds with bated breath. “Ha ha!” Rubin declared, “yes, I can feel it!” he picked up the heavy crate he was carrying like it was a feather. “Yes Rubin, and I can see it” Crom said, pointing at the roo’s gut, almost as fast, the previously trim and fit abdominal was covered in a layer of soft fat. “s-Shutup!” Rubin snapped back and blushed. Crom wouldn’t mention it, but he was sure Rubin’s backside had also just plumped out a little bit, it was hard to stifle his laughter.

The rest of the group was pretty evenly split on if they tried the Strongfat Fruit, as they had uncreatively named it. Bart was quite happy to eat one, but Herc was far too vain to even let an ounce of fat get on his frame.

Nethertheless before they left they stocked up on a large pile of the fruit, who knew how long the effects would last after all, and super strength could always be handy in a bind.

After a little more walking…
15112.title: a weird realm, high calorie fruit

choices: Along the way the group finds a little friendly animal native to this land
Along the way the group finds a big unfreindly enemy native to this land
151121.content:
The second incident of strange happenings in this realm occurred just a few miles down the twisted path they were travelling.

Ahead of them was a river, cradled in black sand, flowing with a bubblegum pink substance not translucent like water but more like milk or cream.

As far as the bandit group could tell it stretched on indefinitely in either direction, though how they would pass it was not clear, their course was clear, they simply had to pass the river.

None of the party would dare traverse the gooey waters, sensibility prevailing. But Herc was growing more frustrated by the minute; they were on a tight schedule, on rout to a goal they knew not how far it would take.

The coyote commissioner, whose name still remained a mystery to Crom and Rubin, seemed equally upset, he was fiercely chastising his wizards for not being able to do something like simply levitate them over the gap.

Suddenly Alec the Druid cried, “Eureka!” He had been quietly performing a spell to sift through the black sand of the riverbank, and he found was he had expected was hidden there.

Another one of the special rune stones had been unearthed. Bruce the mage was asked to read it, lo and behold it described how to cross the river. There was a passage, a bride to lead them over it. The reason none of them had been able to find it was simply because it was invisible!

“Aralek’ mohabi no, tralina sen…” the fox finished reading, “That means, eh, if I did read it right, heh heh… there is one special condition needed to pass the bridge, anyone walking across canNOT look at the water below, not one glimpse, or else they’ll just fall straight down into the waters below!” the mage emphasized dramatically.

“Does it say what might happen if we fall into the water? How do we know we can trust this stone, it might be a trap!” the blacksmith inquired worriedly. “No it doesn’t say, but we’ve been following these stone instructions all the way here, it’s a little late to be wondering if they’re misleading! Besides, unless you can think of some other idea it’s all we have.”

“He right” Herc spoke up authoritatively, “we don’t have any more time to waist, where is this invisible bridge?”
“Right there sir, it should be between the two silver palm trees, and I don’t see any other!”

“Well, since you’re so confident about this, you try it!” shouted the brutish cyan sharmorth Rex, who grabbed the fox by the neck of his robe and pushed him towards the bridge, almost right into the water.

“Hey stop that!” FireHammer the dragon shouted, “I’ve had it up to here with your shit, I’ll turn ya into sushi if you don’t back off!”
“I’d like to see you try!”
“SILENCE, both of you fools!” shouted Herc who drew out his cutlass threateningly.
Tensions were high, the stress was getting to the team, “I’ll go first” Herc volunteered, “afterall, I’m the leader, I lead.”

The white wolf approached the gap between the two silver trees. Took a deep breath, stared up into the pink sky and took a step forward.

It worked! It appeared like he was walking on the surface of the river. Herc let out the tiniest sigh of relief and quickly marched straight across. “Come on men, follow your leader” Perralace yelled, and copied exactly as her lover did. Without needing to be told twice soon everyone was making a quick procession line.

That was when the problem happened, after almost everyone had passed FireHammer was making his slow way across, making sure to look anywhere but below. The auburn dragon was actually quite fearful of water, never learned to swim, not that he could with all the heavy armour he constantly wore.

He had almost made it across, when behind him was Rex, grinning like only a shark could, he had timed this just perfectly. Without warning he lunged forward, walking straight into the burly dragon with enough force to make stumble.

FireHammer tried to correct himself, he tried to keep his eyes closed, but alas for a split second he saw the milky pink goo and then he plummeted under.

There were gasps from the crowd, Herc let out a stream of profanities. Rex just calmly waked to the otherside offering hollow apologies to his leader, pretending he didn’t see him because his eyes were closed.

Meanwhile FireHammer was thrashing about in the water; luckily for him it turned out the river was not deep, only going up to his elbows at most. But he was still in a panic.

He wiped the pink fluid from his eyes as best he could, he wasn’t far from the riverbank. He tried to get over the initial shock since he wasn’t dead, and started to wade through the goo as quick as he could, but it was so thick, and the riverbed was muddy and sticky.

“Rex when I get out of here I’m going to kill you!” he roared, “Eh?... I feel, ulp, funny… is this making my armour shrink!?” the dragon asked, but he was wrong, it was not the armour shrinking, his body was growing.

The dragon stopped to take off his plate armour before it constricted him to death, exposing more skin to the odd pink water.
As he took off his breastplate a large globular belly flopped out, the type of belly you’d expect to see on an heavy ale drinker, a huge difference to the washboard abs FireHammer had sported just a few minutes ago.
“Whaa!?” he yelled in confusion, tentatively poking his still swelling stomach. It was so soft, it felt so unnatural to the blacksmith, to his most surprise though… it actually felt kind of good.

Then he inspected the rest of his body and found to his horror the same was happening everywhere else. His ass was becoming fat and lardy, tail becoming thick and meaty, he had moobs growing larger than most well endowed women, his thighs were touching, soon he would only be able to manage a waddle.

The gang could only look on in amazement as the dragon fellow grew well obese and beyond that. Until Herc snapped out of his stupor and yelled, “Keep moving you idiot!”

That snapped FireHammer out of his shock too, and with a great deal of effort he started moving forward again. By the time he finally reached the otherside he looked like a beached whale. He collapsed on the sand still slightly growing as his body absorbed the last of the goo still on him.

“Errghgh…” he just groaned, exhausted. “C-can you move?” Crusher inquired, clearly concerned for his friend.
“…too… heavy…” the dragon moaned, face in the sand.
“Aww crap, what are we going to do, we can’t just leave him here!” the tiger yelled, “Goddamnit Rex I aught to cut you down right now!”
There was an awkward silence, nobody could think of anything to say, would they really have to leave him here? What other option was there?

“Wait!” Perralace suddenly exclaimed, “Do you think uh.. he hasn’t tried one of those special fruits has he? Maybe if he eats one he’ll be strong enough to stand, and Crusher and Rex… and goddamnit Rex you will help, could help him walk!”
After a little debate and threatening Rex they all agreed, and fed the mountain of a dragon one of the fruit.

“Oh my, it’s working, I feel like… like I’m even lighter than I was before!”, FireHammer thankfully exclaimed. Be he certainly didn’t look it, as he noticeably swelled out just a little fatter.
“Ugh! You don’t feel like that to me lardarse!” shouted Rex, who was trying to help him to his feet with Bart, who was having no problem.

“Well that’s cause you haven’t had any fruit, asshole!” Herc spat out, and shoved a large one into his hands, “and don’t you dare bitch about the weight gain, or I’ll throw you in the river myself!”

Rex grumbled and consumed the fruit whole, a chubby little gut swelled up, the bottom of which pocked out from under his shirt.

Alec the zebra then spoke thoughtfully, “I do not think it’s a coincidence that two size altering, though not directly related objects would exist in this land, especially in such proximity…”
“What are you saying?” asked Perralace
“I believe that… it is the theme of this realm, maybe some sort of insane joke by Sarcous, or maybe some corruption…”
“What? So instead of normal traps trying to kill us, this place will try to fatten us to death? I.. I don’t know what’s worse”
“Maybe Perra, this is all just my assumptions so far, though I should note that neither trap has actually been deadly when they easily could have been, the fruit is even proving somewhat helpful…”

The bandit gang could spend little time dwelling on those thoughts though; they had to press on.
151121.title: Thick Water

choices: "Fine, we'll go with the rodent."
"I'm not going anywhere with traitors."
1511211.content:
The trail seemed to shrink as they trekked onward. Or rather, everything on the trail was just getting much too big. The further along they walked, the larger things seemed to get. Trees with soft and ripe trunks closed in on them on both sides. Meaty vines thicker than spring sausages adorned the canopy above.Even the leaves themselves seemed over encumbered with weight.

This new trial did not slow the gang of bandits, swords made short work of the blubbery plants. A standard steel cutlass sliced through the bark like warm butter. Though our crafty heroes had decided to follow a less strenuous plan. Rubin and Crom stood a short ways behind Firehammer, his new found girth and strength forced the meaty foliage apart. Leaving a much wider trail for them to follow.

"I could do this all day, if not for the view." Rubin grimaced at the sight of bulbous sweaty dragon rolls. "What do you think this Sarcous guy's deal was anyway?"

"I think he had a sick sense of humor." Said Crom. "But it makes sense to me in a way."

"What do you mean?" Rubin raised a brow.

"Well if you think about it, the standard adventuring crowd loves to show off their hard earned adventurer bodies. The fastest way to turn them around would be to fatten them up a bit."

"Yeah, a bit." Rubin gestured to Firehammer's back rolls. "But then why the fruit that makes you stronger too?"

"I...you know what maybe he was just a weirdo."

"Agreed."

Suddenly, the caravan of burglars came to a halt. Crom tried to get a peek around Firehammer, but he was much to large to see around. He glanced up at the Dragon and took a moment to muster up some courage.

"Hey up there, you know why we stopped?" Asked Crom.

"Bart says we've found something." Said the dragon.

At the head of the trail, Alec was pondering over their latest find. It stood maybe four feet tall, and a little over three feet wide. Giving it the comical proportions of a berry. Its colorful fur and stubby appendages did not help at all. It had a long tail with a fluffy nub at the tip. It seemed to be a very round over sized chinchilla.

"Uh...moko Alec una du?"

"Why is he talking to me like that?" The round creature looked out among the startled bandits. "And why are you looking at me like that? You guys are the freaks not me."

"Well, it's just that, you're the first thing out here that speaks a lick of the native tongue out here." Said Alec.

"I take you guys aren't from here." Said the chinchilla-like creature.

"You could say that." Alec replied.

"Stop meandering with it and do something. We are burning daylight here." Herc snarled under his breath.

"Right. Would you mind helping a few strangers out? We're looking for something called 'the Orb of Sarcous.'"

The creature scratched its chin. "I might have heard of something like that."

Alec looked at Herc and shrugged. This was getting them nowhere. Herc gave Alec an urgent look, the zebra shrugged a moment. Herc simply took charge and stepped in front. It was his turn to negotiate. "Alright, do you know where you might have seen it last?"

It was then the creature gave Herc an impish grin. "I don't think a bag of bones like you has any business with the orb."

One part confused, another offended. Herc drew his sword and pointed it at the fluffy creature. His lips drawn back in a snarl. "I'll show you what this bag of bones can do."

The creature held up his paws and shook its head. "You don't understand. You don't match the criteria to be an orb bearer."

Everyone looked at each other. Further dumbfounded by the creature's words. What an interesting pot hole in the road they had encountered. Herc stroked his chin, now intrigued.

"Who does then?"

The creature looked out among the crowd of bandits. His tongue sticking out while his eyes were deep in thought. They immediately lit up when he saw what he was looking for. Herc was now on the edge of his toes, searching the crowd for the proper orb bearer.

"The big fellow over there. He's closest out of you all."

All eyes were now on Firehammer. The weight of attention on his shoulders was much more unbearable than any amount of fat he now hoisted around. He wanted to hide, but he was literally the largest of the crew in sight.

"What are you saying, dragons are the key?" Herc folded his arms. "Only he can hold the orb then."

"Hold it? At his size he might be able to get within a hundred paces of its room without being completely destroyed."

It dawned on Herc what the creature was trying to tell him, and he did not like what he was hearing at all. The wolf squeezed his hand into a fist and growled. "You're joking right?"

" 'fraid not. Eat up little guy. You've got a long ways to go." The creature chuckled and took a seat on his rock. Herc was fuming.. The nature of Sarcous' realm had been revealed.

"Herc, if I'm hearing this right, one of us has to more than double Firehammer's size to even stand in the same room as the orb. I can't fathom what size one must be if they want to hold it." Loagi whispered.

"That's easy enough, we let someone soak in that river until they get big enough."

"At that point I don't even think any amount of fruit from those trees could get someone strong enough to even sit up."

"Ah but there is a way." The creature spoke again. "A way to give you the size you want and the strength to handle it."

"I'm listening, you overfed rodent."

"No need for name calling. I'm here to help." The creature smiled. "There are several pathways throughout the land. Only one is the true way to the size you desire."

"Yes but we could easily just follow the stones for such a path." Said Herc.

"Let me give you a small hint, it is not about the end of an adventure that matters. Rather, it's the journey. Only the strongest can walk this trail."

Herc snarled a little and looked at his crew. The coyote commissioner looked annoyed by this sudden development. The creature before them seemed to know what he was talking about. But he could easily be leading them into a trap. They were told not to trust anything about this realm. What made this beast any different?

"I say we follow him." Said Perralace.

"I say we don't..." Herc shook his head. "This has bad news written all over it. Doesn't seem just a little convenient that at a fork in the road we find someone trying to sway us one way?"

The crew was becoming restless. They knew their time was running out and if someone did not decide soon, they would lose valuable time in actually getting the orb. Bart could sense the general unease from everyone around him. It was time for someone to decide. He took a few steps forward, but someone had already beaten him to it.

"Oi! All of you. Does it matter what this guy says to us if we have true power in our grasp?" Rex called out to crew. "I say we go with the creature. It knows more about this land than anyone of us and besides, our leader here can't even handle a little bit of chub on him. How do you expect him to make decisions that lead us to the orb?"

Oddly enough, the crowd was nodding in agreement with the sharkmorph. Things had suddenly become a power struggle, and Rex as leading it. Herc felt the need to strike down the shark, put him in his place, but his crew was already feeling a little mutinous. The promise of power at the cost of body image seemed fine to plenty of those bandits. He sheathed his sword and looked out to them.
1511211.title: The Proverbial Fork In The Road

choices: they stumble upon a curiously sweet smell.
the path leads them to a seemingly dead end.
15112112.content:
"I'm not going anywhere with traitors." Herc coldly stated, “Any of you, if you want to follow fish-breath and the fuzzball, go ahead. But don’t come crying to me when you walk straight into a death trap.”

He glared scornfully at Rex, who countered with a challenging smirk; the jerk had always been a backstabbing traitor, that’s what the shark such a successful bandit.

“Fine by me” Rex said smugly, “then when we have the orb it’ll just mean one less ego mad puppy to share it with. Who’s with me?”

The crowd of bandits only briefly discussed the matter, nearly all of them agreed; they were heading with Rex and the chinchilla-ish creature. “Hee hee hee, I guarantee, you won’t regret this!” The little round critter chimed.

Initially picking to go with Rex, Crom and Rubin were ready to leave with the rest of the gang, until Crom got cold feet, “Psst, Rubin. Hey Rubin! I think we should stay.”
“Huh, what?” The roo questioned confused, “Crom, why would we want to stay here, with Herc, aka they crazy bandit leader, or ex-leader now… Anyway he’s crazy.”
“Shh! I know I know, but… the more I look at that little native guy, the less I trust him”
“What? But he’s nice! He’s a cute little helpful bowl of jelly.”
“Have you seen the way he looks at everyone, with that creepy glint in his eyes.”
“Now you’re just being paranoid Crom”
“No I’m not, listen, Herc is right, his story doesn’t add up. Please Crom, you ignored me on the fruit… and I’ll admit you seem right about that one, but I’m getting seriously bad vibes here.” Rubin sighed, and relented, “alright, we’ll stick with the crazy we know.” Crom was very pleased Rubin had listened to him this time.

By the time most of the disloyal bandits had left with Rex down the Right Path, there were only eight bandits left with their group, not counting Rubin, Crom or Herc, that was down almost twenty men.

Perralace had decided to stay, even if she thought Herc was wrong she wouldn’t leave him. Alec and Loagi decided to stay too; they seemed to see what Crom felt about the little chinchilla. Bart was Herc’s righthand man, surprisingly loyal. Firehammer was certainly not going to leave with Rex after what he did to him, and Bruce felt the same, though he probably decided moreso to stay because he had a thing for Liz who also chose to stay.
There was one quiet Husky bandit the two hunters had not spoken to yet that stayed as well, for who knows what reason.

The coyote commissioner and his small group of men were another faction, they didn’t follow Rex, but now they didn’t exactly need Herc’s men either. They stood away from them and discussed things in secret.

“Huh? What are you two still doing here?” inquired a brooding Herc to the hunters as they approached, “Why don’t you just run back to the portal door? Missions over.”
“Yeah well about that” Rubin replied, “we were kinda hoping… we could head back with you? We kinda didn’t pay much attention to what direction we were heading in to here cause our view was blocked by a big fat dragon butt” Crom sharply nudged Rubin to not insult anyone, especially not their best bet out of this place at the moment.

Herc was about to respond with ire, but he was interrupted by one of the commissioners wizards, a dark looking antelope with large horns, “I’m to inform Mr. Hercawitz that indeed ‘the mission’ is not ‘over’. Our liege payed for this operation, and only he gets to say when it in fact ‘ends’. He says the mission will go ahead, despite your woeful inability to command your troops.”
“Wha, why you!”
“Silence, you’re on thin ice already. You know if you renege on the deal you signed you’re a dead wolf.”
“Argh, let me talk to him!” Herc yelled, and marched right over to the commissioners group.

Meanwhile Rubin and Crom tried to make conversation, “So uhh, do you guys still have that sack of StrongFat Fruit?” Rubin asked sheepishly, “I know it’s only been a hour or so, but I’m feeling kinda hungry, and I think the strength effect is starting to wear off.”
“Rubin!” Crom scolded, “How can you be thinking of food at a time like this?”
“Hey actually I’m feeling kinda hungry too?” Bart interjected. “Me third” Loagi agreed, “and after all it should be past breakfast time, let’s sit by this rock here and eat.”
Crom could only roll his eyes, “Well do you at least have some normal food that won’t make you fat? I might have some of that.”
Loagi searched their supplies, “Hmm, sorry bunny, only fruit, I guess Rex’s crew took the rest.”
“Hmph” Crom replied.

Everyone but Crom, Perralace and the quiet Husky boy who seemed a bit of a loner, decided to join in on this impromptu brunch. “Oh wow” Liz remarked, “I can’t believe I didn’t try this before, it feels amazing! And tastes great.” She took another bite and her tightly corseted chest seemed to strain against the fabric a little more. “Mmm, yeah, I think this somehow tastes even better than before!” Bart declared, his once toned abs now replaced by a chubby beer gut, “I wonder if I eat two will I become twice as strong?” and reached into the supply bag for seconds.

“Ugh, pigs” Perralace muttered under her breath, Crom was kind of surprised to hear her talk that way about her own party; though with their bandit tablemanners he could hardly disagree.
After they were done Rubin got up and stretched, and then gasped and blushed as some of the studs on his leather armour popped off, a squishy tan-red furry belly pushing out. This time it was obvious the rest of his body had been affected too, his pants now looked one or two sizes too small for his butt, he had the making of love handles and a small muffintop.
“I bet it’ll take you longer than a week to work that off” Crom chided, and poked him in the exposed belly. Rubin instantly swatted Crom’s hand away, “Ugh, I am never eating one of these darn fruit again…” his statement had started strong, but ended sounding very hollow as his eyes laid back on the food sack, he unconsciously licked his lips. “Hmm, well I’m glad to hear that” Crom said, “…Are you alright buddy?” he asked since the roo was seemingly ignoring him, eyes transfixed on the food. “Huh? Yeah yeah I’m fine, those fruit are taste but they sure aren’t very filling…”

Before Crom could respond to that a much more cheerful Herc strode up to the group, “Guess what, missions not over boys, our fine sponsor had a few ace up his sleave it turned out. Pack up your tea party time’s a wastin”

Without bothering to elaborate the wolf started hiking up the Left Path, “We’re going to be rich!” he yelled back to them and started laughing.

Perralace ran to catch up with her paramour, “Huh, so what is it? How are we not stuffed right now.”
“Keheheh, as we suspected that bastard Maxwell had sponsored some other bandit groups than us, for insurance, and yesterday in the battle we fought, it was with one of them, fucking Cobalt Gang. 151121121.content:
Trudging along the Left Pass for a short while soon turned into an absolute drudgery, the ground was slick and muddy, making each step a little bit harder, and the pink sky overhead was becoming difficult to see as it was eclipsed by the thick tree branches up above, dimming their light source.

“-huff huff- Are you sure this is the right direction Herc?” questioned Loagi, the black bear clearly not enjoying the current conditions, “I can hardly see what’s ten feet in front of me, how’d ya know we’re even still on the correct path?”
“If you want us to head back now and go down the Rightward Path that’s not happening Loagi, just have a little faith in your leader, kay? Look, if you have any doubt ask Bruce, he’s the mage”

Behind them were Rubin and Crom, forbidden from trailing behind Firehammer’s behind after the roo’s quip earlier.
“You and your fat mouth Rubin”
“Me?? You’re the one who suggested we ask them to take us back instead of just figuring out a way back for ourselves, we could be out of here by now if it wasn’t for you.”
“Or we could be even more lost than we are currently, face it, unless you suddenly learn how to read ancient stone language we’re stuck with these guys.”
“I still say we could have figured it out… I wish I had something to eat right now”
“What, again?!”

Behind them were Alec and Perralace, discussing various theories about this land, and what to think of their sudden change in affiliation from the Basalt Brigand to the Cobalt Gang. They didn’t like it.

Behind them was Maxwell the commissioner and his gang, all the mud seemed to be a little too much for the pompous coyote, who was in shoes more fit for waltzing than for hiking.

Behind them was Firehammer, who was having trouble keeping up with the rest of the pack.

Behind him was… there should have been the Mage Fox, Panda Archer and Loner Husky, but they were all missing!

Five minutes ago they were all there, but when Loagi went to ask Bruce about their current path direction it suddenly became apparent that they were gone.

“Great… just fucking great!” Herc cursed at this new distraction, “Where could they have got to? They better have not fucking turned back!” shouted the wolf infuriated.

“I can use an old tracking spell I know to lead us too them, if they wandered off the path” Alec spoke, and started to wave his druid staff over the ground muttering a strange language. “Ku lo ra, rama si skai, misapek ‘Liz’, misapek ‘Bruce’, misapeck ‘Rocky’!”
Suddenly three small orbs of light arose from the ground, “They will take us too them” the zebra said confidently.

They only had to backtrack for a little while before they saw their direction diverged from the group. In to a less dense area of foliage, but strangely less well lit, there was an odd amount of flowers and vines draping the trees that surrounded this place. And for the first time they saw weird red coloured vines, which pulsed like they were alive, it grossed Crom out. There was an odd aura about this place, it was different than the rest of the forest, it even smelled different, faintly sweet thanks to all the yellow flowers he guessed.

The light orbs vanished back into the ground. “Their path…” the druid spoke confused, “ends here?” But there were nowhere to be seen.

Herc gritted his teeth, he looked like he was about to blow a gasket. Crom rested his back on one the surrounding trees, this was really tiring work for those without superstrengh. That odd smell about this place, it was pretty sickening Crom thought, but also… enticing in a way? He took a deep breath; it actually smelled pretty good on second opinion. It was making him more hungry than he already was. If only he could… find the source of that smell… then everything would be fine… everything would be perfect…

One of the thick bright red vines was circling all around Crom, wrapping around his arms, legs and even his ears! After it had finished binding the intoxicated rabbit the end of the vine slid easily into Crom’s eager mouth, which began sucking as if on cue, drawing a sap like substance out of the tip.

“Crom!” a frightened Rubin yelled out, as soon as he noticed what was happening to his buddy. He drew his sword, and moved to cut down the wicked vines, but nimbly the plant hoisted the white rabbit up in the air, high up above them all.

It was then the group realize that the reason this area was worse lit than the more densely crowded forest was because their three missing crewmembers and now Crom were being suspended from the treetops, each sucking contently from a pulsing red vine. The missing crew were almost as hopelessly fattened as Firehammer by now, and the skinny Crom was already not so skinny anymore, sporting a gut that was bloating larger with sap by the second.

“We’ve got to do something!” yelled Loagi, who drew a dagger and started cutting the surrounding trees franticly.
He sliced a nearby red vine, it burst with a spray of intoxicating smell and sap.
The black bear was hit by the brunt of it, and almost instantly became as complacent as the other trapped team members. The two cut ends seem to come alive, and shot straight down the alchemist’s throat, pumping gushing sap into his belly. In his sudden haze he didn’t even try to stop it as it shoved him onto his butt and started filling his belly at more than twice the speed of the others. Not even having to suck like the others, the two cut vines just gushed into him like a large hose.

“Oh fuck” yelled Herc, witnessing this and realizing simply cutting the vines wouldn’t be effective.

The sap in Crom’s swollen belly was turning into pure fat now. He was already surpassing Rubin’s weight. But he was nothing compared to the balls of fat were the others. How the vines even had the strength to lift them was astounding. The husky “Rocky” was the lightest of the three, but that was not saying much, he had triple chins and a huge grey fur dome like belly, his over taxed tunic would surly give any second now. Liz’s corset had popped a long time ago, large triple D breasts wobbled about and were squeezed by the twisting vines, she looked like she had a expression of pure bliss on her face as she sucked down the gooey amber. Her tremendous panda tush was the largest part about her, like two big white moons in the sky.
But poor Bruce, the once so lean fox, was the hardest hit. By now he looked well beyond Firehammer’s weight, his busted robe was no match for such a massively overstuffed belly. He was just a blob of orange and white, dangling in the air by a few red strings.

Loagi’s gut was now spilling over his sides; it was forcing his meaty legs apart as it brushed the floor. He just murmured in delight like a total zombie.

Rubin jumped about the battlefield, trying to keep track of Crom and trying to avoid the red vines which were suddenly much more active, perhaps sensing the intruders. Everything was a pandemonium; some wanted to retreat to safety, other to save their teammates.
By accident Rubin landed on one of the numerous yellow flowers that populated his area, crushing it.
Suddenly the vines in the surrounding area seemed to spasm, then they slowly dropped to the ground, dead.

Taking a second to realizing what he’d done Rubin yelled, “The flowers! Kill the flowers!”

And with that the battle was easily won, in mere moments the vines suspending their grossly fattened comrades began to descend gracefully, thankfully, it would be a right mess if it just dropped them out of the sky.

The kangaroo grabbed the rabbit as he landed, and effortlessly ripped off the limp red vines and tattered leather chest armour. Crom’s droopy eyes slowly returned to dilation, and he yawned like he had just been put under a deep sleep. “…Uhh, what happened?” he drowsily inquired, but his eyes opened wide in shock as they travelled down past Rubin’s face and to the white expanse of fat that was his belly. “Ahh ahh, w-what happened?!” he yelped, and grabbed two handfuls of doughy flesh, jiggling them about. “Heh heh, long story, but I’m guessing this will take you over a month to burn off, fat-butt” the kangaroo sniggered, now more worried about giving a scaving teasing payback now that he knew his friend was okay. “Look Crom you even have the start of little moobs.” And he poked his chest.
Very shortly Rubin got a sharp fist to the gut.

Alec inquired about the health of his teammates, they had mobility, but only just, and Rocky had to be force fed one of the Strongfat Fruits despite his instance he could still make it without them.

---

Back on the path, the group really just hoped that would be the last hassle they encountered before reinforcements arrived. But luck was not on their side today, for almost as soon as they began moving forward again did they hear a terrified yell for help, coming from up ahead.

It was Jang, one of the twin cat assassins, by chance heading straight in their direction, but there was one huge difference from normal Jang, this cat was almost unrecognizably fatter! He had wide puffy cheeks, a big black belly that sloshed about with every step he took, his assassin top had ridden up that plush furry dome and nestled in his large cat moobs. He wasn’t looking where he was going and almost ran (or more like fast waddled) right into Herc. When he actually saw everybody he was so startled he slipped face first into the mud.

“B-boss?” he whimpered, apprehensive to be looking right at the bandit leader he just deserted, but also seemingly relieved to find anyone in this wild.

Herc grinned a with deep satisfaction, “Keheheh, so what happened?”

1511211211.content:
The newly fattened assassin took a moment to stand again. His limbs shook and trembled under his new weight. He panted and huffed, trying to catch his breath. It took way longer than he was used to for his stamina to return. Jang wiped the mud from his face and looked behind him, partially relieved that he had somehow managed to escape.

"Alright...here's the story..."

~~

Rex and his crew obeyed the rodent's every command, every step of the way. In fact all went well for awhile. No traps, no monsters, nothing. The chinchilla revealed its name to be "Bal," which brought forth some laughter. This did not bother Bal at all, he only continued to lead them on through the woods.

Then they reached a small village. Everywhere they looked were those adorable berry shaped chinchilla things of all colors. Most were a little amused at the sight, but not Rex. He was quite annoyed. As far as he knew, they were not getting any closer to the orb. He could tell.

"We are wasting time, those others could find it before we do." Rex said.

Bal assured everyone that without his help, finding that orb was going to be no easy task. The other guys were stupid for leaving. Rex wasn't satisfied. He wanted to leave and keep going. Bal wanted to rest. Then Rex did something he really shouldn't have. The shark morph struck the chinchilla creature on the back of the head, this brought forth the ire of the entire horde. In an instant a flurry of these creatures had pounced on Rex. No longer adorable, but quite frightening. Rows of sharp teeth and their claws were incredibly long. They were no match for Rex's strength, at least while he had it. After a few bites from the creatures, the shark began to tucker out. The change was slow, but he was definitely getting bigger.

Everyone else tried to run, some were lucky and managed to get away. Others not so much. Jang was caught by surprise on the trail out of the village. Two ambushed him and bit him on the arm. He managed to toss the thing aside, but it didn't take long for him to feel the effects of the venom. It took a good hour before he really started to notice it, and it wouldn't stop. What really terrified the cat, was the fact that Rex had taken multiple bites. Jang only got, at most, 3 bites, and he was huge.

~~

"Then I ran into you guys, I dunno how far I ran but you know I'm glad I'm out of there." Said Jang, slumping down on his rear and wincing. His legs were starting to feel the burn.

Herc glanced at the feline's arms, noticing a bite mark or two. Just like he had mentioned in his tale.

"Looks like you guys had a little trouble too." Jang panted.

"Had a run in with malevolent foliage." Herc shook his head. Half of his crew was hardly recognizable at this point. A nagging fear at the back of his mind pervaded his thoughts for a moment. Was he next? He shook his head, no, he had worked too hard for it to be that way again.

The party surrounded Jang, he felt nervous, now that he was back again with the crew. They all seemed too tired to really care that he had ran out on them. Bart was first to grab some of the strong fat fruit and offer it to the cat. Jang shook his head.

"It'll help, the last thing you should be worried about is your figure at this point."

"No I feel stuffed, I couldn't eat a bite." Jang grimaced as he tried to stand again. Bart helped him up a little, Jang's legs wobbled as he spread out his stance. But for the moment he was fine.

Meanwhile, Herc and Perralace were talking.

"What if that thing was taking them somewhere before Rex pulled that stunt." She snapped. "Now we're stuck with our rival gang, half of us are blobs or well on the way, and we have no idea where we're going."

"Just shut up and let me think." Herc glared. "We'll keep with the stones, after a short break to let our reinforcements play catch up."

"So we wait while anything could happen? Do you really want to risk that?"

"You know you're really starting to get on my nerves." Herc's hackles raised a little.

"I'm getting on your nerves? I thought we were partners. You know, watch eachothers backs and make decisions together."

"If we went with that little rodent we'd all be like Jang right about now. So how about you quit the bitching and just accept that you were wrong and we figure something else out."

Perralace glared daggers into Herc. She let out a humorless chuckle and took a seat. "You know I'm starting to miss the days when you were a fat kid, not as good looking in bed, but you know what, not such a bastard either."

Herc's eye twitched a little, his hand gearing to strike, when a loud groan shook them from their argument. Jang was leaning up against a tree for support, moaning about his stomach. His eyes grew wide as the sounds of stitches giving filled the air. What was left of his clothes were starting to tear. Fur and flab peeked out from the stretched seams. His legs trembled as they filled out more and more. Pushing his stance wider and wider. Eventually the weight was too much and he collapsed on his rear. He tried to stay sitting up, but his mountain of a gut pushed back into him. His limbs flailed around, his cries starting to become muffled. His cheeks puffed up more and what was left of his neck disappeared beneath another chin. A loud "snap" sounded off as what was left of his clothes tore apart. His constricted moobs bouncing free. The added weight was running out of places to go, now it was simply pooling around him, limply settling in every direction it could. Anyone listening could hear his body gurgling and his skin literally stretching to accommodate his growing size. His gut rose and fell with his breathing. It had stopped for now, but no one knew how long.

"The venom must still be working in his system!" Loagi gasped, grimacing as he stood, his new weight proving a bit of an annoyance as well.

"What do we do? We leave him like that and he's going to...well...drown in himself." Perralace shook her head.

"Perhaps I can make an anti-venom. I held onto my alchemic supplies, if I had a sample of the venom we could at least try to stop it...what say you Herc?"

Herc glanced down at his former crew member. His panicked eyes glanced all over the place. It seemed like the only thing he could do was breath and move his eyes.
